prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection of spiral waves in the disk of HD135344B

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary science goal of our observations is to look for the sub-millimeter counterparts of the spiral arms seen in scattered light in the protoplanetary disk around HD135344B. We are looking for the spirals in the continuum as well as in the J=2-1 transition of two CO isotopologues, 12CO and 13CO. Although C18O is likely too faint to be detected with the proposed observations, the line is covered by our correlator setup, as a bonus. Since our prime interest is the intensity distribution in the disk and not the kinematics for the line observations we use a spectral resolution of 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) for all lines. The expected line-width is 5km/s. To maximize the continuum sensitivity and stil be able to measure all CO lines simultaneously we set up the correlator in the following way.
Baseband 1: We used one spectral window in FDM mode centered at 230.7GHz rest frequency with a bandwidth of 468.75MHz to observe the CO J=2-1 line at a rest frequency of 230.538GHz. A spectral resolution of 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) was used for this spectral window. Three other spectral window was used within this baseband with 468.75MHz bandwidth and 488kHz channel spacing to measure the continuum. The central frequencies of the three continuum spectral window was set to 231.2GHz, 231.7GHz and 232.19GHz respectively. To keep the data rate the lowest possible we average 16 channels for all continuum spectral windows.
Baseband 2: We used one spectral window set to TDM mode and centered at 234.0GHz to measure the continuum.
Baseband 3: We used one spectral window for continuum in TDM mode centred at 217.0GHz.
Baseband 4: We use four spectral window in FDM mode, each with a bandwidth of 468.75MHz. We set the central frequency of one spectral window to 220.2GHz to measure the 13CO J=2-1 line while another spectral window was centered at 219.7GHz to observe the C18O line. The spectral resolution was 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) for both spectral windows. Two more spectral windows were used in this baseband for the continuum centered at 219.2GHz and 218.71GHz, respectively. The channel spacing of these two continuum spectral window was set to 488kHz. To keep the data rate the lowest possible we do spectral averaging by 16 channels in both continuum spectral windows.
With this corraltor setup we measure all three CO isotopologues simultaneously while in the same time we keep the 7.5GHz aggregate continuum bandwidth. Keeping the widest possible bandwidth is important and helpful for phase calibration especially for high spatial resolution/long baseline observations used in this science goal.

Scattered light images at 0.05"-0.07" spatial resolution indicate that the width of the spirals is not resolved even at this resolution. For spatially unresolved surface density perturbation the contrast strongly depends on the angular resolution (higher contrast for higher spatial resolution). It is, therefore, of vital importance to use very similar angular resolution in the ALMA observations as in scattered light. Therefore we chose to use an angular resolution of 0.05 arcsecond that matches the angular resolution of scattered light imaging. Lower angular resolution would lead to lower contrast between the spiral and the disk or would result in not resolving the spirals radially. Higher angular resolution observation would result in lower surface brightness sensitivity. According to the Technical Handbook such high resolution / long baseline observation are offered as standalone mode/configuration, therefore the largest angular scale is set by that of this configuration. We request a largest angular scale of 0.47 arcsecond which is the largest value we can have without the need for a second, extra configuration. At this settings we expect to filter out some of the background disk. Therfore we will observe the disk also at a lower angular resolution in a separate science goal to measure the disk and recover larger scale structures. Our modeling suggests (see Figure 2 in Scientific Justification) that the two datasets have enough overlap in the spatial frequencies to be combined into a single image that contains all spatial scales necessary for our science case.

In this science goal we aim at detecting the sub-millimeter counterparts of the spirals in the disk around HD135344B seen in scattered light observations. Since we are interested in the intensity distribution in the disk and not in the kinematics we chose the lowest resolution FDM mode for the correlator. Since we will measure spectral lines and continuum simultaneously our sensitivity requirement is set by the more demanding line observations. Based on our models that matches the contrast of the scattered light observation and the brightness of the source in lower spatial resolution sub-millimeter observations we expect to see a temperature fluctuation of about 30K in 12CO and about 20K in 13CO (see Figure 2 in the Scientific Justification). To detect such perturbation in the 13CO integrated intensity map with at least 3sigma significance in the channel maps we require an rms noise of 0.72582391mJy equivalent of about 6.67K per spectral resolution element (1.269km/s or 0.9765MHz).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observation of the disk around HD135344B

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary science goal of our observations is to look for the sub-millimeter counterparts of the spiral arms seen in scattered light in the protoplanetary disk around HD135344B. We are looking for the spirals in the continuum as well as in the J=2-1 transition of two CO isotopologues 12CO and 13CO. Although C18O is likely too faint to be detected with the proposed observations, the line is covered by our correlator setup, as a bonus. Since our prime interest is the intensity distribution in the disk and not the kinematics for the line observations we use a spectral resolution of 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) for all lines. The expected line-width is 5km/s. To maximize the continuum sensitivity and stil be able to measure all CO lines simultaneously we set up the correlator in the following way.
Baseband 1: We used one spectral window in FDM mode centered at 230.7GHz rest frequency with a bandwidth of 468.75MHz to observe the CO J=2-1 line at a rest frequency of 230.538GHz. A spectral resolution of 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) was used for this spectral window. Three other spectral window was used within this baseband with 468.75MHz bandwidth and 488kHz channel spacing to measure the continuum. The central frequencies of the three continuum spectral window was set to 231.2GHz, 231.7GHz and 232.19GHz respectively. To keep the data rate the lowest possible we average 16 channels for all continuum spectral windows.
Baseband 2: We used one spectral window set to TDM mode and centered at 234.0GHz to measure the continuum.
Baseband 3: We used one spectral window for continuum in TDM mode centred at 217.0GHz.
Baseband 4: We use four spectral window in FDM mode, each with a bandwidth of 468.75MHz. We set the central frequency of one spectral window to 220.2GHz to measure the 13CO J=2-1 line while another spectral window was centered at 219.7GHz to observe the C18O line. The spectral resolution was 1.27km/s (488kHz channels pacing) for both spectral windows. Two more spectral windows were used in this baseband for the continuum centered at 219.2GHz and 218.71GHz, respectively. The channel spacing of these two continuum spectral window was set to 488kHz. To keep the data rate the lowest possible we do spectral averaging by 16 channels in both continuum spectral windows.
With this corraltor setup we measure all three CO isotopologues simultaneously while in the same time we keep the 7.5GHz aggregate continuum bandwidth. Keeping the widest possible bandwidth is important and helpful for phase calibration especially for high spatial resolution/long baseline observations used in this science goal.

Observations in this science goal are complementary to our other science goal ("Detection of spiral waves in the disk of HD135344B") to recover large scale structures. We plan to combine the two dataset to create a single high dynamic range image. Using simulated observations we show in Figure 2 in the Scientific Justification that the combination of the two data set to a single image is possible. We chose the largest angular scale to be 2 arcsecond to recover all spatial scales in the disk. The disk expected to have a diameter of between 1 arcsecond to 2 arcsecond. The spatial resolution of the observations was chosen to be 0.2 arcecond to have enough overlap in spatial frequencies with the observations in our other science goal from this proposal. Our final goal is to combine the two data sets from the two scince goals into a single coherent image.

In this science goal we aim at observing the disk around HD135344B both in the CO lines and in the continuum. Since we are interested in the intensity distribution in the disk and not in the kinematics we chose the lowest resolution FDM mode for the correlator (1.269km/s). Since the primary purpose of this science goal is to combine these data with the high resolution observation from our other science goal ("Detection of spiral waves in the disk of HD135344B") we would need the two configuration to have roughly the same surface brightness sensitivity. However, to reach a the same surface brightness sensitivity of about 6.67K / spectral resolution element (1.269km/s) as used/requested for the long baseline science goal, it takes only about 2min on-source integration time for a spatial resolution of 0.2arcsecond. A 2 minutes integration time would be too short for imaging. Since the goal of the project is to detect perturbations/ features in the surface brightness distribution in the disk that can be related to physical perturbations image quality is important for us. Our modeling shows that for a 20min integration time, equivalent of 2.3mJy (or 1.37K) per spectral resolution element (1.269km/s or 0.9765MHz), the uv-coverage is good enough that we can image the desired features in the disk with high confidence.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Spiral arms have been observed in about half a dozen protoplanetary disks in near-infrared scattered light. They were widely regarded as the signposts of embedded planets and an important evidence for in-situ formation of wide separation planets. Recently our team showed that the spirals seen in scattered light might not be perturbations of the surface density in locally isothermal disks as previously thought but rather temperature / scale height perturbation. To determine the nature of the perturbation and measure its amplitude at different vertical heights, we propose to observe the disk around HD135344B with ALMA both in the continuum and in CO emission lines. Our team has access to the latest highest contrast and resolution scattered ligth images from the SPHERE GTO program. The comparison of scattered light images to the ALMA measurements will shed light on the physical conditions in the spirals which are invaluable informations for theoretical models of planet migration. With these observations we can constrain the driving mechanism of the spirals and test some of the fundamental assumptions used in theoretical models such as the locally isothermal equation of state.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
